x_l: If you want to watch the Earth rotate on its axis, there's a way to do it in your very own living room -- or anywhere else you happen to have access to a pair of binoculars. By looking at the sky, you can track and measure the rotation of the planet. The system is actually much more complicated than that. But a new technique developed by researchers in Japan allows them to precisely calculate when the planet's rotation will occur, giving them precise data for use in a global positioning system or other applications. They published the results of their work today in Nature Communications.
y_orig: [Watch the Earth's rotation on a computer screen] [Watch a video of the Earth rotating] The researchers used a technique called time-resolved laser interferometry (TLI), which measures the time it takes for light to travel from one point to another.

x_l: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday issued a new notice to manufacturers of certain electronic cigarettes, vowing to crack down on the devices' sale to minors.
